title: Disgraced NHS boss lands new job - at the trust next door
text:

A disgraced NHS chief who quit his job after colluding to sack a sexual harassment victim has walked straight into another plum role – at the mental health trust next door. 
Professor Steve Trenchard resigned from his £150,000-a-year post as chief executive of Derbyshire Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust a year ago, after a court ruled employee Helen Marks had been wrongly forced out of her job. 
It has now emerged that just five months later he was hired by neighbouring Greater Manchester trust Pennine Care as a consultant project director. 
Pennine Care says the scandal at his previous trust, which cost £1.4m of taxpayers’ money, is a ‘separate issue’ and has no bearing on his new role. 
But Mrs Marks has accused him of having ‘no shame’ – while MPs have also slammed the appointment as ‘appalling’ and vowed to raise it with the health secretary. Read More Son of Frank Sidebottom creator Chris Sievey has died following crash in Withington 
Prof Trenchard became embroiled in scandal at Derbyshire after HR director Mrs Marks accused the then-chair of the trust, Alan Baines, of sexual harassment. 
It was later ruled that Mr Baines had indeed sexually harassed her – before branding her a ‘whore’ when she spurned his advances. 
But instead of taking action, Prof Trenchard colluded with him to push Mrs Marks out by accusing her of bullying, before having her escorted from the building. 
Mrs Marks instructed solicitors and successfully sued for wrongful dismissal. 
The tribunal ruled in April 2015: “We are satisfied that Professor Trenchard and Mr Baines colluded in an attempt to dismiss the claimant or alternatively obtaining her resignation.” 
Despite the trust suggesting Mrs Marks had ‘led’ Mr Baines on, it also concluded: “There was not a shred of evidence to suggest that at any stage she had indicated that she would be willing to enter into a sexual relationship with him.” Helen Marks 
Mrs Marks was awarded £800,000 in damages and received an apology from the trust. 
Prof Trenchard was then suspended for seven months, earning £90,000 while not at work. 
Last February he resigned with a £75,000 pay-off. 
We can now reveal that just five months after quitting Derbyshire, Prof Trenchard was hired by Pennine Care – which provides mental health services to a million patients across Oldham , Bury, Rochdale, Tameside, Glossop, Stockport and Trafford – as an external consultant. 
The trust, whose chief executive Michael McCourt also sits on the board of mental health body Positive Practice with Prof Trenchard, confirmed he had been hired on a two-day-a-week contract last July but refused to disclose his salary. Read More Inquest opens into death of Stephen 'Aki' Akinyemi who was shot dead at Arran Coghlan's mansion 
It did not directly answer whether his new post had been advertised but said he had been hired ‘in line with trust procedures’ and was known to Pennine Care ‘through various mental health networks’. 
Mrs Marks, who has said she will never work again in the NHS after the ordeal, reacted with horror to the news. 
“It is disgraceful that after all this and receiving £90k whilst suspended and not working, and a further £75k as a payoff, he has now returned to work in a senior post in the NHS, despite assurances from the regulators that it is difficult for such individuals to return to the NHS,” she said. 
“He has no shame.” 
Derbyshire MP Pauline Latham, who has repeatedly criticised Mr Trenchard’s pay-out, said she was ‘astonished’. Barbara Keeley said she was ‘appalled’ by the appointment (Photo: Jen Urwin) 
“Do they really want someone working there who has such a stain on his character?” she said. 
“It’s worrying that the health service seems to look after their own – and not care about the people they damage en route. This is supposed to be a caring organisation that is dealing with very vulnerable people and they should have people of the highest calibre.” 
Shadow health minister Barbara Keeley said she was ‘appalled’ by the appointment, adding: “I have raised in the past this unacceptable ‘revolving door’ culture in the NHS where staff move on to be paid in new NHS posts after findings against them result in resignations and pay-offs. 
“I will be raising this issue with health secretary Jeremy Hunt and asking him to look at this as a matter of urgency.” 
After the tribunal ruling in 2015 health regulator Monitor – which has since been renamed NHS Improvement – opened an investigation into ‘governance concerns’ at Derbyshire, which subsequently issued a series of criticisms over its leadership and HR processes. 
Pennine Care refused to say who provided references for Prof Trenchard but said he was hired thanks to his ‘wealth of knowledge and experience of leading front-line mental health services’. Read More House fire that killed mum and dad not being treated as suspicious 
The trust’s chief executive Michael McCourt said: “Professor Trenchard has been commissioned to work for Pennine Care for two-days a week as a private consultant to develop a new mental health strategy for the trust. 
“This is a significant and complex programme of work, requiring additional senior capacity to complete it within a relatively short time frame. Therefore, Prof Trenchard was selected based on his wealth of knowledge and experience of frontline mental health services. 
“The trust was made aware of the tribunal details and the reasons for leaving his previous role. 
“The matter was openly discussed with Prof Trenchard prior to his appointment. 
“Directors concluded it was a separate matter that did not relate to the work he was expected to carry out on the trust’s behalf. 
“Prof Trenchard reports progress directly to an executive director. His work to date has been very well-received and has helped the trust make positive progress with its strategy. 
“Prof Trenchard is a champion for service users and carers and he has brought a helpful focus to our planning.” Read More
